_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Supermarkets and Other Grocery (except Convenience) Stores

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
SuperValu Foods Distribution Center, Anniston, Alabama operates an ammonia refrigeration system to produce

space cooling, product cooling, and process equipment cooling.

The SuperValu Foods Distribution Center refrigeration system is designed to provide:

Operating flexibility (through availability of multiple operating equipment combinations);

Efficiency of operations (through the use of operating pressures commensurate with the degree of cooling

required and alternative fuel / energy equipment);

Safety performance (through multiple safety systems that can shutdown the system and minimal use of

ammonia liquid pumps, utilizing instead the pressure differentials established in the system to move liquid

refrigerant); and

Consistency of operation, utilizing programmable logic controllers (PLCs) to monitor, record, operate, and

modulate refrigeration equipment as conditions require.

Emergency Systems

The ammonia refrigeration system has several safety features. In the event of a liquid ammonia leak, the king

valves (outlet of the high pressure liquid receiver) can be closed automatically or manually to prevent flow of

ammonia liquid to downstream equipment. The system can be shutdown by the computer control system or by

two emergency stop stations located: 1. In the engine room at the north exit; and, 2.Outside the engine room

back door.

In addition, ammonia sensors located in the engine room and in all ammonia refrigerated areas can shutdown

the ammonia system when ammonia concentrations reach unacceptable PPM levels (>15PPM).

The facility is equipped with a sprinkler system.

Response Capabilities

The facility is an evacuation facility with trained maintenance staff that can assist fire department / haz-mat responders in a limited manner.

Ammonia System Summary

Major equipment components include:

5 Compressors

51 Evaporators

2 Evaporative Condensers

1 Purger

3 Liquid Recirculators

6 Ammonia Pumps

1 High Pressure Liquid Receiver

1 Controlle

d Pressure Receiver

1 Ammonia Storage Tank

Ammonia inventory: 22,900 lbs.

Ammonia system operators: Three

Ammonia System Contractor: Southeastern Refrigeration, phone: 205-322-6587

Process Safety Management/Risk Management Program Description

The facility has a fully implemented process safety management / risk management program including:

Employee Involvement is to provide guidelines for employee open access to Process Safety Management

information and to provide guidelines for employee involvement in the development and implementation of

Process Safety Management.

Process Safety Information organizes the documentation and availability of written process safety information,

pertaining to hazards of the chemicals used, the technology, and equipment covered in the process. The

management system identifies the currently available information and establishes guidelines for producing

additional information.



Process Hazards Analysis provides the structure for identifying, evaluating, and controlling processes involving

anhydrous ammonia.

Process Hazard Analysis Team defines the selected employees who shall participate in the formal PSM program

activities based on their familiarity with the ammonia refrigeration system.

Operating Procedures defines the format, structure, and change method for specific procedures developed for

operating the ammonia refrigeration system. These procedures and practices are critical in maintaining a safe

operation.

Training defines the requirements and establishes the process for initial and follow-up operations training for all

employees working in hazardous areas. The material is then developed to meet the specific training

requirements, and must include verification of training and employee training documentation.

Contractor Control organizes contractor safety programs in the plant and ensures that the critical aspects of

working in a hazardous area are included in the program. This includes specific record keep

ing requirements

associated with contractors working in hazardous areas.

Pre-startup Safety Review provides guidelines for reviewing new or modified hazardous facilities prior to startup.

These guidelines require that the facility is installed in accordance with design specifications, confirms that the

Process Safety Information is updated and accurate, operating procedures are in place, and training is

completed prior to startup.

Mechanical Integrity organizes and documents, through the establishment of procedures, existing maintenance,

testing, quality assurance, and inspection practices to maintain the ongoing integrity of process equipment.

Hot Work Permits enhances and implements existing hot work practices and permits used in the ammonia

refrigeration system areas. The system ensures that the procedures are adequate to provide proper protection in

a hazardous chemical area.

Management of Change establishes and implements written procedures for managing all changes to the

process. This management system includes provisions for ensuring that the changes are correctly performed,

documented, training is conducted, and reflected in the applicable Process Safety Information.

Process Safety Incident Investigation enhances existing procedures and practices to prevent recurrence of

process safety incidents.

Emergency Planning and Response clarifies and confirms the existing facility plans containing complete

provisions for responding to any emergencies involving anhydrous ammonia.

Compliance Audits establishes the protocol for conducting process safety audits every three years, including the

written report and documentation of deficiency corrections.

Trade Secrets documents guidelines for open exchange of safety-critical information and protection of company

secrets.
